rvi.caption: Return settings in rounded format while running PyMOL via the RCP server ipymol in a jupyter notebook. This is a modified version of the roundview.py script.

kernel.caption: A kernel.json file for runnig PyMOL python interpreter in the Jupyter notebook. This code should reside in a folder named pymol.python in the ~/Library/Jupyter/kernels.

pymoldocs.caption: Return to the command history window the docstrings for all of the functions in a module.

numResiProtein.caption: Print the number of residues in a protein.

numResiProteinChainA.caption: Print the number of residues in chain A of a protein.

numResiNucleic.caption: Print the number of residues in a nulceic acid (all chains).

numResiNucleicChainA.caption: Print the number of residues in a nulceic acid chain.

brokenNucleicBackbone.caption: Create bonds between phosphorous and O3* atoms in a low-resolution DNA structure that is 80 base pairs long.

oneBondThicknessColor.caption: To change stick color and radius for the bond between atom 2 and 3, use the set_bond command.

drawLinks.caption: Connect the alpha carbons of residue 1 with 10, 6 with 16, 7  with 17 and 8 with 18. Note that this example requires the draw_links.py [http://pldserver1.biochem.queensu.ca/~rlc/work/pymol/draw_links.py] by Robert Campbell.

printPath.caption: Print the path to the currently used PyMOL binary.

presetDocs.caption: Return the docustring for the preset submodule. The command help preset fails to return anything. The command help(pymol.preset) has the same effect as help(preset).

helpDocs.caption: Return the docustring for the help submodule. This command is more concise:  help help.

loadAmberTrajs.caption: The amber trajectories have to be loaded into the same object.

saveSeppy.caption: Saves multiple objects into multiple files using an optional prefix name.

optAlignRNA.caption: OptiAlign.py by Jason Vertree modified for aligning multiple RNA structures.

loadManyFiles.caption: Load into PyMOL multiple files with a common file stem. The is a script by Robert Campbell that has been updated for Python3.

loadAndAlignManyFiles3.caption: These are the instructions for loading and aligning multiple files.

allPairs.caption: This is a two-fold nested list comprehension for any all-parwise operation on the currently loaded objects. Replace optAlginRNA with object from any other function that operations on a pair of structrures.

dssrBlock1.caption: Combining DSSR block representation with regular PyMOL cartoons after loading the dssr_block.py script by Thomas Holder.

dssrBlock2.caption: DSSR block representation with fused blocks after loading the dssr_block.py script by Thomas Holder. The x3dna-dssr executable needs to be in the PATH.

dssrBlock3.caption: DSSR block representation for a multi-state example after loading the dssr_block.py script by Thomas Holder. The x3dna-dssr executable needs to be in the PATH.

dssrBlock4.caption: DSSR block representation with custom coloring after loading the dssr_block.py script by Thomas Holder. The x3dna-dssr executable needs to be in the PATH.

nucleicAcidCartoon2Strands.caption: Coloring two strand differently of a double helix makes it easier to for the viewer to distinguish the two strands. The set command has the syntax of setting_name [, setting_value [, selection [,state ]]] . In this case, the selection has to be global, object, object-state, or per-atom settings. It cannot be a named selection. This is a weak spot in PyMOL. Coloring two strand differently of a double helix makes it easier to for the viewer to distinguish the two strands. Many double-stranded helices have one strand in the asymmetric unit. The second strand is in the biological unit. The coordinates for the second strand are in the pdb1 file type at the PDB. The second strand is in the second state, which is equivalent to the second model in the pdb file. The strands are labeled chain A and B (via the cartoon_nucliec_acid_color setting). The bases are colored differently too (via the cartoon_ladder_color setting).

nucleicAcidColorbySequence.caption: This code colors the nucleotides by base seqence. It can be applied to any nucleic acid.

nucleicAcidFlatRibbonColorbySequence.caption: This code colors the nucleotides by base seqence. It can be applied to any nucleic acid. It is dervied from the CR shortcut. The backcone is shown as a flatten ribbon.

nucleicAcidCartoonFilledRings.caption: The code provides a cartoon of the loaded nucleic acid that has the ladder rungs replaced by filled rings that are colored by atom type. The code can be applied to any nucleic acid. It is derived from the FR shortuct in pymolshortcuts.py.

basePairStacking.caption: This code make as standard base stacking diagram with ball and stick representation.

nucleicAcidDumbellCartoonColorbySequence.caption: This code colors by the nucleotides by base seqence. The backcone is shown as a flatten ribbon with rolled edges that give the dumbell effect. The code can be applied to any nucleic acid. The code is dervied from the CR and DU shortcuts.

stereokb.caption: Set keyboard shortcut by mapping F1 to stereo.

listSettings2.caption: Print to the screen the settings and their current parameter values.

listSettings.caption: Print to the screen the settings and their current parameter values. This is the more compact version.

displayFonts.caption: Print to the screen as labels the 21 font ids in their corresponding fonts in a grid. Each label is an object and appears in the internal gui. You can turn on and off the display of specific fonts.

listObjects.caption: Create a list of objects in the internal gui and print this list to the screen.

listLigandProteinDistances.caption: Print a list of protein--ligand distances. Code by Dan Kulp. Updated for Python3.

nucleicAcidBackboneTubesSticks.caption: This code shows the cartoon backbone tube as 65% transparent. It hides the rungs of the cartoon. It shows all of the non-H atoms are sticks. The motivation is to have the cartoon highlight the backbone without dominanting the scene.

symexp.caption: The code expands the asymmetric unit. It like the generate symmetry mates command but it provides more control over the prefix name of the symmetry mates and the addition of unique segment identifiers for each symmetry mate. The usage: symexp prefix, object, (selection), cutoff, segidFlag. The cutoff is in Angstroms. The segidFlag set to 1 will add unique segids. For related functions, see SC***.

addAxis.caption: Adds the function draw_axis(). Used to a symmetry axis, a ncs axis, or scale bar to a scene.

synch.caption: Wait unitl all current commands have been executed. A timeout ensures that that command ecentually returns.

renumResi.caption: Add or substract a residue number offset.

renumAtoms.caption: Add or substract a atom number offset.

printAtomNumbers.caption: Print the atom number2 of a residue.

printAtomNames.caption: Print the atom names of a residue.

printBfactors.caption: Print the bfactors of a residue.

printVDWradii.caption: Print the van der Waals radii of the atoms in of a residue.

printCoordinates.caption: Print the coordinates of the atoms in a residue.

printNamesCoordinates.caption: Print the atom names and coordinates of the atoms in a residue.
Print the atom names as tuples and coordinates of the atoms in a residue as a list.

addAxispy.caption: Adds the function draw_axis(). Could be useful for the adding a symmery axis, a ncs axis, or scale bar to a scene.

grayscalepy.caption: Apply grayscale coloring using a grayscale version of the PyMOL colors for the elements. This is a Python function. It is invoked in a script file via gscale(). There is a corresponding gscale shortcut in pymolshortcuts.py that is invoked in a pml script by entering gsale if the functions in pymolshortcuts.py have been loaded with the run pymolshortcuts.py command.

importShortcuts.caption: Import for loading the functions in the pymolshortcuts.py file. These functions can be run inside cmd.do() without the trailing (). For example, cmd.do('rv')..

rv.caption: Run the rv function from the pymolshortcuts.py file.

AO.caption: Run the AO function from the pymolshortcuts.py file to generate the photorealistic effect.

AOBW.caption: Run the AOBW function from the pymolshortcuts.py file to generate photorealistic effect in grayscale.

AOD.caption: Run the AOD function from the pymolshortcuts.py file to generate photorealistic effect with carbons colored black.

AODBW.caption: Run the AODBW function from the pymolshortcuts.py file to generate photorealistic effect with carbons colored black and all other atoms colored in grayscale.

unitCellEdgesColorBlack.caption: Color unit cell edges black. The settings for controlling the unit cell color are hard to find.

printColorByAtomCodes.caption: Print the codes for color-by-atom (util.cba*) alternates.

grayscale.caption: Apply grayscale coloring using a grayscale version of the PyMOL colors for the elements. This is a Python function. It is invoked in a script file via grayscale(). There is a corresponding gscale shortcut in pymolshortcuts.py that is invoked in a pml script by entering gsale if the functions in pymolshortcuts.py have been loaded with the run pymolshortcuts.py command.
